questions.text: Shahrukh, 31-year-old man was found to have Elevated cholesterol levels of 325 mg/dL on a routine checkup. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 42, and also had greatly elevated cholesterol levels throughout his life. The man’s physician placed him on lovastatin, and his cholesterol levels dropped to 170 mg/dL. The nature of the elevated cholesterol in this patient is most likely due to a mutation in which one of the following proteins?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) LDL receptor This patient most likely has familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), a genetic disorder characterized by significantly elevated cholesterol levels due to mutations in the LDL receptor gene. The LDL receptor is responsible for the uptake of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol from the bloodstream into cells. In FH, mutations in the LDL receptor impair this process, leading to high levels of circulating LDL cholesterol and increased risk of cardiovascular disease. The fact that the patient’s cholesterol levels were significantly reduced with the use of lovastatin, a statin that inhibits HMG-CoA reductase (the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis), further supports the diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia. Statins reduce cholesterol synthesis, which may help to upregulate the remaining functional LDL receptors, leading to the reduction in cholesterol levels. Incorrect Answers: A. HMG-CoA reductase HMG-CoA reductase is the enzyme involved in cholesterol synthesis, and statins like lovastatin inhibit this enzyme to lower cholesterol levels. However, a mutation in HMG-CoA reductase would not explain the elevated cholesterol levels in this patient. Familial hypercholesterolemia is typically due to defects in the LDL receptor and not HMG-CoA reductase. Therefore, this option is incorrect. B. ACAT ACAT (Acyl-CoA: cholesterol acyltransferase) is an enzyme involved in esterifying cholesterol for storage and transport. While defects in ACAT may lead to abnormal lipid metabolism, they do not typically cause the elevated cholesterol levels seen in familial hypercholesterolemia. ACAT dysfunction would likely lead to issues related to cholesterol storage and metabolism, not high circulating cholesterol levels. Thus, this option is not relevant. D. Lipoprotein lipase Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is an enzyme that breaks down triglycerides in lipoproteins, such as chylomicrons and VLDL. A mutation in LPL could lead to hypertriglyceridemia but would not typically cause elevated cholesterol levels in the way seen in this patient. Since the issue here is elevated cholesterol, rather than triglycerides, LPL is not the correct answer.

questions.text: A 5-month-old child exhibited extreme tiredness, irritable moods, poor appetite, and fasting hypoglycemia associated with vomiting and muscle weakness. Blood work showed elevated levels of free fatty acids, but low levels of acylcarnitine. A muscle biopsy demonstrated a significant level of fatty acid infiltration in the cytoplasm. The most likely molecular defect in this child is in which one of the following enzymes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer B. Carnitine transporter The clinical presentation of this 5-month-old child — extreme tiredness, irritability, poor appetite, fasting hypoglycemia, vomiting, muscle weakness, elevated free fatty acids, and low acylcarnitine levels — is suggestive of a defect in the carnitine transporter. The carnitine transporter is responsible for facilitating the transport of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria, where they are oxidized for energy production. A defect in this transporter leads to the inability of long-chain fatty acids to enter the mitochondria, causing the accumulation of fatty acids in the cytoplasm and decreased production of acylcarnitine (which is necessary for mitochondrial fatty acid oxidation). The resulting inability to properly metabolize fatty acids leads to muscle weakness, hypoglycemia, and other symptoms seen in this child. The muscle biopsy showing fatty acid infiltration further supports this diagnosis. Incorrect Answers: A. Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) is an enzyme involved in the mitochondrial beta-oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids. While a deficiency in MCAD would lead to fasting hypoglycemia and elevated fatty acids, it would typically cause elevated levels of acylcarnitine in the blood as well, because fatty acids are converted into acylcarnitine for transport into the mitochondria. The child in this case has low acylcarnitine levels, which is inconsistent with an MCAD deficiency, making this option incorrect. C. Acetyl-CoA carboxylase Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of malonyl-CoA, which plays a role in regulating fatty acid metabolism. A defect in acetyl-CoA carboxylase could cause issues with fatty acid metabolism but would not explain the specific pattern of elevated free fatty acids and low acylcarnitine seen in this child. This enzyme is not directly involved in the transport of fatty acids into the mitochondria, so it is not the most likely cause. D. Carnitine acyltransferase II Carnitine acyltransferase II is responsible for transferring fatty acids from acylcarnitine back into the mitochondria for oxidation. A defect in this enzyme would also impair mitochondrial fatty acid oxidation and lead to an accumulation of acylcarnitine. However, this child has low acylcarnitine levels, which makes a defect in carnitine acyltransferase II unlikely. This makes option D incorrect.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the hospital with complaint of a fusiform swelling of the Achilles tendon, which, when biopsied, shows cholesterol-laden macrophages (foam cells) dispersed among the collagen fibers. She had gives a chronic history of joint pain. Both her mother and father developed arthritis associated with production of xanthomas, but their first symptoms occurred in middle age. She was referred to a nutritionist and treated with an enzyme inhibitor. Which of the following is most likely elevated in the blood of this woman?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Low density lipoproteins (LDL) The woman described in the case most likely has familial hypercholesterolemia, a genetic disorder that leads to elevated levels of low-density lipoproteins (LDL) in the blood. This disorder is caused by mutations in the LDL receptor or other proteins involved in LDL metabolism, leading to decreased clearance of LDL from the bloodstream. This results in the accumulation of cholesterol in the blood and the development of xanthomas (cholesterol deposits in the skin and tendons) and other cardiovascular issues, which is consistent with her presentation. The foam cells (cholesterol-laden macrophages) seen on biopsy are indicative of a cholesterol overload, further supporting the diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia. The enzyme inhibitor mentioned likely refers to a statin or other lipid-lowering medication aimed at reducing LDL levels. Incorrect Answers: A. Chylomicron remnants Chylomicron remnants are the remnants of chylomicrons after they have delivered triglycerides to peripheral tissues. In familial hypercholesterolemia, the primary issue is the elevated LDL levels, not chylomicron remnants. Therefore, chylomicron remnants would not be expected to be elevated in this case. B. Chylomicrons Chylomicrons are lipoproteins that transport dietary fat (triglycerides) from the intestines to other tissues. Elevated chylomicron levels are more typically associated with lipoprotein lipase deficiency or other disorders affecting triglyceride metabolism. This does not match the clinical picture of the patient, whose primary issue is related to LDL metabolism, not chylomicron metabolism. C. High density lipoproteins (HDL) HDL is considered the "good" cholesterol because it helps remove excess cholesterol from peripheral tissues and transport it to the liver. In familial hypercholesterolemia, HDL levels are typically normal or even reduced, but they are not the primary lipid abnormality. The problem in this case is an elevation in LDL, not HDL.

questions.text: Which of the following fatty acid has maximum number of carbon atoms
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cervonic acid. Explanation for the correct response: Cervonic acid is a polyunsaturated fatty acid with 24 carbon atoms. It is also known as docosatetraenoic acid (DTA). This fatty acid has the maximum number of carbon atoms compared to the other fatty acids listed, which makes it the correct answer. Explanation for the incorrect responses: B. Oleic acid: Oleic acid is a monounsaturated fatty acid with 18 carbon atoms. It is widely found in olive oil and other vegetable oils. While it is a common fatty acid, it has fewer carbon atoms than cervonic acid. C. Linolenic acid: Linolenic acid is an essential polyunsaturated fatty acid with 18 carbon atoms. It has three double bonds and is found in flaxseeds, chia seeds, and walnuts. Its carbon count is lower than that of cervonic acid. D. Arachidonic acid: Arachidonic acid is a polyunsaturated fatty acid with 20 carbon atoms. It is an important precursor in the biosynthesis of eicosanoids and is present in animal tissues. Despite being crucial for inflammation and signaling, it has fewer carbon atoms than cervonic acid.

questions.text: Phospholipids are included in which group of lipid classification
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Complex lipids. Explanation for the correct response: Phospholipids belong to the group of complex lipids. Complex lipids are characterized by their structure, which includes fatty acids, a glycerol backbone, and a phosphate group, along with another molecule (such as choline, ethanolamine, or serine). This complex structure differentiates phospholipids from simple lipids, which only consist of fatty acids and alcohol. Phospholipids are crucial components of biological membranes, and they play an important role in cell structure and signaling. Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. Simple lipids: Simple lipids consist of fatty acids and alcohols, and they include triglycerides and waxes. Phospholipids are not classified as simple lipids because they contain additional components, such as phosphate groups, which make them more complex. C. Derived lipids: Derived lipids are products that are derived from simple or complex lipids, such as fatty acids, glycerol, and sterols. Phospholipids themselves are considered complex lipids, not derived lipids. D. Sterol: Sterols, such as cholesterol, are a class of lipids with a distinct structure that includes a four-ring steroid nucleus. Phospholipids are not sterols, as they contain different structures with fatty acids and phosphate groups.

questions.text: All of the following membrane lipids except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Triacylglycerol. Explanation for the correct response: Triacylglycerol (also known as triglyceride) is not a membrane lipid. It is a type of simple lipid that consists of three fatty acids bound to a glycerol molecule. Triacylglycerols serve primarily as energy storage molecules in adipose tissue and are not involved in the structure of cell membranes. In contrast, membrane lipids are critical components of biological membranes, contributing to membrane integrity and function. Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. Lecithin: Lecithin is a type of phospholipid, specifically phosphatidylcholine, and is a major component of cell membranes. It is essential for the structure and function of biological membranes. B. Phosphatidylserine: Phosphatidylserine is another phospholipid that is an important part of cell membranes, especially in the inner leaflet of the bilayer. It plays a role in cell signaling and apoptosis. C. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is a type of sphingolipid found in the membranes of animal cells, particularly in the myelin sheath surrounding nerve cells. It contributes to membrane stability and signaling.

questions.text: All of the following contain alcohol group except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Docosahexaenoic acid. Explanation for the correct response: Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) is a polyunsaturated fatty acid, and it does not contain an alcohol group. DHA is part of the omega-3 fatty acids family and is essential for brain and eye health. While fatty acids like DHA play an important role in the body, they do not have alcohol (-OH) groups in their structure. Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. Glucocerebroside: Glucocerebroside is a type of glycosphingolipid, which contains a sugar (glucose) attached to ceramide. Ceramide itself contains a long-chain alcohol group, so glucocerebroside does indeed contain an alcohol group. B. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is a type of phospholipid that contains sphingosine, which has an alcohol group. Therefore, sphingomyelin contains an alcohol group. C. Lecithin: Lecithin is a phospholipid (phosphatidylcholine) that contains a choline group and fatty acids. The glycerol backbone of lecithin is attached to an alcohol group as part of its structure.

questions.text: Which of the following is monoenoic acid
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Oleic acid. Explanation for the correct response: Oleic acid is a monoenoic acid, meaning it contains only one double bond in its carbon chain. Oleic acid is an unsaturated fatty acid with 18 carbon atoms and one cis double bond at the 9th position (C9). This single double bond classifies it as a monoenoic acid (from "mono-" meaning one and "-enoic" referring to the presence of a double bond). Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. Linoleic acid: Linoleic acid is a polyunsaturated fatty acid, containing two double bonds in its carbon chain. It is classified as an omega-6 fatty acid, making it a dienoic acid rather than a monoenoic acid. C. Linolenic acid: Linolenic acid is also a polyunsaturated fatty acid but contains three double bonds. It is classified as an omega-3 fatty acid, making it a trienoic acid rather than a monoenoic acid. D. Arachidonic acid: Arachidonic acid is another polyunsaturated fatty acid, containing four double bonds. It is an omega-6 fatty acid and is classified as a tetraenoic acid, not a monoenoic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a saturated fatty acid
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Linoleic acid. Explanation for the correct response: Linoleic acid is not a saturated fatty acid. It is a polyunsaturated fatty acid, meaning it contains two double bonds in its carbon chain. This classification makes it unsaturated rather than saturated. Linoleic acid is an omega-6 fatty acid and plays an important role in various biological processes, including the production of signaling molecules. Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. Palmitic acid: Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid. It contains 16 carbon atoms with no double bonds in its structure, which makes it fully saturated with hydrogen atoms. B. Stearic acid: Stearic acid is also a saturated fatty acid. It consists of 18 carbon atoms and is fully saturated with no double bonds. D. Myristic acid: Myristic acid is a saturated fatty acid. It contains 14 carbon atoms and is fully saturated with no double bonds in its structure.

questions.text: Most essential fatty acid is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Linoleic acid. Linoleic acid is an essential fatty acid because the human body cannot synthesize it and it must be obtained through the diet. It is a polyunsaturated omega-6 fatty acid, playing a crucial role in various metabolic functions, including being a precursor for eicosanoids, which are involved in inflammation, blood clotting, and cell signaling. Since our body cannot produce linoleic acid, it is considered essential for normal growth, skin health, and overall metabolic processes. Incorrect Options: A. Palmitic acid: Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid and is not considered essential because the body can synthesize it from carbohydrates through the process of fatty acid synthesis. It is commonly found in both animal and plant fats, but it is not required in the diet. B. Arachidonic acid: Arachidonic acid is an omega-6 fatty acid, but it is not essential because the body can synthesize it from linoleic acid, the essential fatty acid. It is important for inflammatory responses and the formation of eicosanoids, but it is not directly required from the diet. D. Linolenic acid: Linolenic acid is an essential fatty acid, but it refers to alpha-linolenic acid, an omega-3 fatty acid. While essential, it is not the most essential fatty acid in the context of this question compared to linoleic acid, which is more directly involved in several crucial metabolic processes.

questions.text: Fatty acid which is not synthesized by human
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Linoleic acid. Linoleic acid is an essential fatty acid, meaning the human body cannot synthesize it and must obtain it from the diet. This polyunsaturated omega-6 fatty acid is vital for various physiological functions, such as cell membrane structure and the production of eicosanoids, which regulate inflammation and other bodily processes. Incorrect Options: A. Oleic acid: Oleic acid is a monounsaturated fatty acid that is synthesized by the human body. It can be produced from stearic acid, which is an 18-carbon saturated fatty acid, through desaturation. Oleic acid is abundant in olive oil and other vegetable oils. B. Stearic acid: Stearic acid is a saturated fatty acid that can be synthesized by the human body. It is derived from the metabolism of carbohydrates and is commonly found in animal fats and some vegetable oils. D. Palmitic acid: Palmitic acid is also a saturated fatty acid and can be synthesized by the human body. It is one of the most common fatty acids found in human tissues and is produced from carbohydrates and dietary fats.

questions.text: Maximum source of linoleic acid is found in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sunflower oil. Sunflower oil is one of the richest sources of linoleic acid, containing a high percentage of this essential omega-6 fatty acid. Linoleic acid makes up a significant portion of sunflower oil, usually around 60-70%, which is why it is considered one of the best sources of this fatty acid. Incorrect Options: A. Coconut oil: Coconut oil is primarily composed of saturated fats, especially lauric acid. While it contains a small amount of polyunsaturated fats, including linoleic acid, the proportion is much lower compared to sunflower oil. B. Vanaspati: Vanaspati is a type of hydrogenated vegetable oil, which is high in trans fats. While it may contain some linoleic acid, the hydrogenation process alters the fatty acid profile, making it a less significant source of linoleic acid compared to other oils. C. Palm oil: Palm oil contains some linoleic acid, but it is more abundant in saturated fats, specifically palmitic acid. It is not as high in linoleic acid as sunflower oil, which makes it a less ideal source of this essential fatty acid.

questions.text: Which of the following fatty acid is cardioprotective
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Omega-3 fatty acids. Omega-3 fatty acids, particularly EPA (eicosapentaenoic acid) and DHA (docosahexaenoic acid), are considered cardioprotective. They are known to reduce inflammation, lower blood pressure, decrease triglyceride levels, and improve overall heart health. Omega-3 fatty acids also help reduce the risk of arrhythmias and improve endothelial function, making them beneficial for cardiovascular health. Incorrect Options: B. Stearic acid: Stearic acid is a saturated fatty acid. While it does not have the negative cardiovascular effects that some other saturated fats may have, it is not considered specifically cardioprotective. In fact, the body metabolizes it into oleic acid, which is not as beneficial for heart health as omega-3 fatty acids. C. Oleic acid: Oleic acid is a monounsaturated fatty acid found in olive oil and other vegetable oils. While it is heart-healthy due to its ability to improve lipid profiles and reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease, it is not as specifically cardioprotective as omega-3 fatty acids, which offer more profound anti-inflammatory and heart-health benefits. D. Palmitic acid: Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid that, when consumed in excess, can contribute to the development of heart disease. It is not considered cardioprotective and is more likely to increase the risk of cardiovascular problems due to its effects on cholesterol levels and inflammation.

questions.text: Which fatty acid exclusively present in breast milk
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA). DHA is a long-chain omega-3 fatty acid that is uniquely abundant in breast milk compared to other food sources. It plays a crucial role in the development of the brain and retina in infants. Breast milk provides DHA in an easily absorbable form, ensuring optimal neurological and visual development during the early stages of life. While DHA can be obtained from other dietary sources, its presence in breast milk is critical for infant growth and is one of its unique benefits. Incorrect Options: A. Palmitic acid: Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid that is present in breast milk, but it is not exclusive to it. It is also found in a variety of other foods, including animal fats and palm oil. Unlike DHA, palmitic acid does not have specific developmental benefits tied exclusively to breast milk. C. Linoleate: Linoleate, or linoleic acid, is an essential omega-6 fatty acid that is present in breast milk. However, it is not unique to breast milk, as it is commonly found in plant-based oils such as sunflower, safflower, and corn oils. D. Linolenic acid: Linolenic acid, also known as alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), is an essential omega-3 fatty acid found in breast milk. However, like linoleate, it is not exclusive to breast milk and is present in various plant oils, such as flaxseed and chia seed oils. It also serves as a precursor for DHA synthesis in the body.

questions.text: Essential fatty acid are beneficial in preventing following condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Atherosclerosis. Essential fatty acids, such as omega-3 (e.g., alpha-linolenic acid, eicosapentaenoic acid, and docosahexaenoic acid) and omega-6 (e.g., linoleic acid), play a key role in preventing atherosclerosis by improving lipid profiles, reducing inflammation, and preventing plaque buildup in the arteries. Omega-3 fatty acids help lower triglycerides, reduce blood pressure, and inhibit platelet aggregation, all of which reduce the risk of atherosclerosis and associated cardiovascular diseases. Incorrect Options: A. Oedema: Oedema, which is the accumulation of fluid in tissues, is not directly prevented by essential fatty acids. While fatty acids contribute to maintaining cell membrane integrity and overall vascular health, they do not have a primary role in addressing the underlying causes of oedema, such as heart failure, kidney disease, or protein deficiencies. B. Nephritis: Nephritis refers to inflammation of the kidneys, which is often caused by infections or autoimmune conditions. While omega-3 fatty acids may have anti-inflammatory properties that could theoretically benefit kidney inflammation, there is no strong evidence that essential fatty acids play a direct preventive role in nephritis. D. Diabetes mellitus: Essential fatty acids may provide indirect benefits in managing diabetes mellitus by improving lipid profiles and reducing inflammation. However, they are not directly preventive against diabetes, as the condition is primarily caused by insulin resistance or autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells. Their role is more relevant to reducing complications associated with diabetes, such as cardiovascular diseases.

choices.text: Linoleic and linolenic acid are cis derivatives containing double bond
Arachidonic acid contains five double bonds
Monoenoic acid has one double bond at 9th position
Linoleic acid is present in soyabean oil

questions.text: All of the following statements are true except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Arachidonic acid contains five double bonds. This statement is incorrect because arachidonic acid is a polyunsaturated fatty acid containing four double bonds (at the 5th, 8th, 11th, and 14th carbon positions). It is a 20-carbon omega-6 fatty acid that serves as a precursor for the synthesis of eicosanoids, such as prostaglandins, thromboxanes, and leukotrienes. The claim that it contains five double bonds is factually inaccurate. Incorrect Options: A. Linoleic and linolenic acid are cis derivatives containing double bonds: This statement is correct. Both linoleic acid (an omega-6 fatty acid) and linolenic acid (an omega-3 fatty acid) are unsaturated fatty acids with double bonds in the cis configuration, which introduces kinks into their structure and affects their fluidity. Linoleic acid has two double bonds (at the 9th and 12th positions), while linolenic acid has three double bonds (at the 9th, 12th, and 15th positions). C. Monoenoic acid has one double bond at the 9th position: This is a correct statement. Monoenoic acids, such as oleic acid, are fatty acids with a single double bond, which is typically found at the 9th carbon in naturally occurring fatty acids. This double bond is in the cis configuration, which contributes to the structure and properties of the fatty acid. D. Linoleic acid is present in soybean oil: This is correct. Soybean oil is a rich source of linoleic acid, which is a polyunsaturated omega-6 fatty acid. Linoleic acid constitutes a significant portion of the fatty acid composition of soybean oil and is an essential nutrient for humans.

questions.text: Auto oxidation occurs in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Arachidonic acid. Auto-oxidation is the process of spontaneous oxidation of unsaturated fatty acids in the presence of oxygen. Arachidonic acid, a polyunsaturated fatty acid with four double bonds, is highly susceptible to auto-oxidation due to its multiple double bonds, which are reactive to oxygen. This process results in the formation of free radicals, hydroperoxides, and other reactive oxygen species, which can lead to lipid peroxidation and cell damage. The high number of double bonds makes arachidonic acid more prone to oxidation compared to saturated or monounsaturated fatty acids. Incorrect Options: B. Stearic acid: Stearic acid is a saturated fatty acid, meaning it has no double bonds in its structure. Saturated fatty acids are resistant to oxidation because they lack the reactive double bonds that would interact with oxygen, making auto-oxidation unlikely. C. Cholesterol: While cholesterol can undergo oxidation, the process is not termed "auto-oxidation" in the same context as fatty acids. Cholesterol oxidation typically requires enzymatic or chemical reactions, leading to the formation of oxysterols. However, cholesterol is not as reactive to spontaneous oxidation as polyunsaturated fatty acids like arachidonic acid. D. Palmitic acid: Palmitic acid is another saturated fatty acid that, like stearic acid, does not contain double bonds. This lack of unsaturation renders it resistant to auto-oxidation, making it stable under normal conditions and not prone to spontaneous oxidation.

questions.text: Maximum content of medium chain fatty acid is present in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Coconut oil. Coconut oil is the richest source of medium-chain fatty acids (MCFAs), which are fatty acids with a chain length of 6 to 12 carbon atoms. MCFAs, such as caprylic acid (C8), capric acid (C10), and lauric acid (C12), constitute a significant portion of coconut oil's composition. These fatty acids are easily absorbed and metabolized by the body, providing a quick source of energy and potential health benefits such as improved digestion and antimicrobial properties. The high concentration of MCFAs makes coconut oil unique compared to other oils. Incorrect Options: A. Flaxseed oil: Flaxseed oil is rich in alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), an omega-3 fatty acid, rather than medium-chain fatty acids. ALA is a long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acid, so flaxseed oil does not have a significant content of MCFAs. B. Fish oil: Fish oil is a source of long-chain omega-3 fatty acids such as eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA). These are long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids and not medium-chain fatty acids, making fish oil unrelated to the context of MCFAs. D. Sunflower oil: Sunflower oil is primarily composed of long-chain fatty acids, such as linoleic acid (an omega-6 fatty acid) and oleic acid (a monounsaturated fatty acid). It contains negligible amounts of medium-chain fatty acids, so it is not considered a significant source of MCFAs.

choices.text: There are not deposited in adipose tissue

questions.text: True for medium chain fatty acids
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above. Medium-chain fatty acids (MCFAs) possess unique metabolic properties that make all the statements accurate: Diffuse directly into portal circulation: Unlike long-chain fatty acids, which require incorporation into chylomicrons and transport via the lymphatic system, MCFAs are absorbed directly from the intestinal lumen into the portal vein. This is because of their smaller size and solubility, enabling rapid transport to the liver. Don’t require pancreatic lipase: MCFAs are hydrolyzed more efficiently by gastric lipase and do not depend heavily on pancreatic lipase for digestion. This property is especially beneficial in conditions where pancreatic function is compromised. Not deposited in adipose tissue: MCFAs are rapidly oxidized by the liver to produce energy and are less likely to be stored as fat in adipose tissue compared to long-chain fatty acids. This makes them a quick energy source and useful in certain therapeutic diets. Incorrect Options: A. Diffuse directly into portal circulation: This is a correct statement, as explained above. MCFAs bypass the lymphatic system and enter the liver directly, making this property distinct from long-chain fatty acids. B. Don’t require pancreatic lipase: This is also true. MCFAs are efficiently hydrolyzed in the stomach by gastric lipase and do not heavily depend on pancreatic enzymes, unlike long-chain fatty acids, which require bile salts and pancreatic lipase for proper digestion. C. There are not deposited in adipose tissue: This statement is correct. MCFAs are preferentially used for energy production in the liver through beta-oxidation rather than being stored in adipose tissue. This metabolic pathway contributes to their unique role in energy metabolism.

questions.text: Small chain fatty acid absorbed from which site
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ascending colon. Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), such as acetate, propionate, and butyrate, are primarily produced in the colon by the fermentation of dietary fibers by gut microbiota. These SCFAs are absorbed in the colon, especially in the ascending colon, where the concentration of microbial fermentation is highest. SCFAs play a significant role in maintaining gut health, providing energy to colonocytes, and regulating various metabolic processes. Incorrect Options: A. Ileum: The ileum is involved in the absorption of nutrients such as vitamin B12, bile salts, and some water, but it is not a significant site for SCFA absorption. SCFAs are primarily produced and absorbed in the colon, not the small intestine. B. Rectum: The rectum is the terminal part of the colon and primarily functions as a storage site for feces. While SCFA absorption can occur throughout the colon, the majority of absorption happens earlier, particularly in the ascending and transverse colon. C. Duodenum: The duodenum is the first segment of the small intestine, responsible for the digestion and absorption of nutrients like carbohydrates, proteins, and lipids. It does not play a significant role in SCFA absorption, as SCFAs are not produced in the small intestine but in the colon.

questions.text: Which reaction occurs due to peroxidation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rancidity. Rancidity refers to the unpleasant odor or flavor that develops in fats and oils due to chemical changes, particularly lipid peroxidation. During peroxidation, unsaturated fatty acids undergo oxidative degradation when exposed to oxygen, heat, or light. This process produces free radicals, hydroperoxides, and secondary oxidation products like aldehydes and ketones, which are responsible for the characteristic rancid smell and taste. Peroxidation is a major cause of rancidity in foods containing unsaturated fats. Incorrect Options: B. Hydrogenation: Hydrogenation is a chemical reaction in which hydrogen is added to unsaturated fatty acids, converting them into saturated or partially saturated fats. This process increases the stability of fats and prevents peroxidation rather than being caused by it. Hydrogenation is used industrially to solidify oils and produce products like margarine. C. Soap formation: Soap formation, also known as saponification, occurs when fats or oils react with a strong base (like sodium hydroxide) to produce glycerol and soap. This is a chemical process unrelated to peroxidation or oxidative degradation of fats. D. Saponification: Saponification is the process of breaking down triglycerides into glycerol and fatty acid salts (soap) using an alkali. While it involves fats and oils, it does not involve oxidation or cause rancidity, making it distinct from peroxidation.

questions.text: Trans fatty acid is a
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Eladic acid. Eladic acid is a trans fatty acid formed by the partial hydrogenation of unsaturated fats. It is the trans isomer of oleic acid (a monounsaturated fatty acid) with the double bond in the trans configuration. Unlike cis fatty acids, which have a bent structure, trans fatty acids like eladic acid have a linear structure, making them behave more like saturated fats. Trans fats are associated with negative health effects, including an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, as they raise LDL (bad cholesterol) and lower HDL (good cholesterol). Incorrect Options: A. Stearic acid: Stearic acid is a saturated fatty acid with no double bonds, so it cannot be classified as a trans fatty acid. It is found in animal fats and some plant fats and is considered relatively neutral in terms of its effects on blood cholesterol levels. B. Arachidonic acid: Arachidonic acid is a polyunsaturated omega-6 fatty acid with four cis double bonds. It is not a trans fatty acid and does not undergo the structural changes characteristic of trans isomers. Arachidonic acid is a precursor for the synthesis of eicosanoids, which are involved in inflammatory processes. C. Oleic acid: Oleic acid is a cis monounsaturated fatty acid commonly found in olive oil. It has a bent structure due to the cis configuration of its single double bond. While oleic acid has a natural cis isomer, it can be converted into its trans isomer (eladic acid) during partial hydrogenation, but oleic acid itself is not a trans fatty acid.

questions.text: Which of the following fatty acid is harmful for health
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Trans fatty acids. Trans fatty acids are harmful to health because they negatively impact lipid profiles and increase the risk of cardiovascular diseases. They raise levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL, "bad cholesterol") while reducing high-density lipoprotein (HDL, "good cholesterol"). These fats are created through the partial hydrogenation of unsaturated fats, a process used in producing margarine and processed foods. Trans fats are also associated with systemic inflammation, insulin resistance, and obesity, contributing to several chronic health conditions. Due to their adverse health effects, many countries have implemented regulations to reduce or ban trans fats in food products. Incorrect Options: A. Mono-unsaturated fatty acids (MUFAs): MUFAs, such as oleic acid, are beneficial for health. Found in foods like olive oil, avocados, and nuts, they help reduce LDL cholesterol levels and improve heart health. MUFAs also have anti-inflammatory properties and support overall metabolic function. B. Cis-saturated fatty acids: This option is misleading because saturated fatty acids do not have cis or trans configurations. Saturated fatty acids lack double bonds, so the concept of cis or trans does not apply. While excessive intake of saturated fats has been linked to increased cholesterol levels and potential cardiovascular risks, they are not inherently harmful in moderate amounts as part of a balanced diet. C. Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs): PUFAs, such as omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, are essential for health. They play crucial roles in reducing inflammation, supporting brain function, and maintaining cardiovascular health. However, an imbalance between omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acid intake can have adverse effects, but this does not make PUFAs harmful in general.

choices.text: Refining of oils cause removal of trans fatty acid
Arachidonic acid can be synthesized from linoleic acid
Hydrogenation converts unsaturated fatty acid into saturated fatty acid
Linoleic Acid is non -essential fatty acid

questions.text: Followings are true for long chain fatty acids except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Linoleic acid is a non-essential fatty acid. This statement is incorrect because linoleic acid is an essential fatty acid. It cannot be synthesized by the human body and must be obtained through the diet. Linoleic acid is an omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acid and is crucial for various bodily functions, including cell membrane structure and the production of eicosanoids, which regulate inflammation. As the body cannot produce linoleic acid, it is considered essential. Incorrect Options: A. Refining of oils causes removal of trans fatty acid: This statement is true to some extent. Refining oils through processes like bleaching and deodorizing can reduce the amount of trans fatty acids, which are often produced during partial hydrogenation. However, it is important to note that not all trans fats are removed, depending on the degree of hydrogenation. B. Arachidonic acid can be synthesized from linoleic acid: This statement is correct. Arachidonic acid, an omega-6 fatty acid, is synthesized from linoleic acid through a series of enzymatic processes. Arachidonic acid plays a role in inflammation and is a precursor to eicosanoids like prostaglandins and leukotrienes. C. Hydrogenation converts unsaturated fatty acid into saturated fatty acid: This statement is also correct. Hydrogenation is a chemical process where hydrogen atoms are added to unsaturated fatty acids, which results in the conversion of some or all of the double bonds into single bonds, making the fat more saturated. This process can create trans fatty acids, depending on the conditions used.

questions.text: Which marker is used to assess lipid peroxidation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Malondialdehyde. Malondialdehyde (MDA) is a key marker used to assess lipid peroxidation, a process in which reactive oxygen species (ROS) cause the oxidative degradation of lipids, particularly polyunsaturated fatty acids. MDA is a reactive aldehyde and a byproduct of the breakdown of peroxidized lipids. It can be measured in biological samples, such as blood or urine, and is widely used as an indicator of oxidative stress and cellular damage related to lipid peroxidation. Elevated levels of MDA are associated with various diseases, including cardiovascular disease and cancer. Incorrect Options: A. CRP (C-reactive protein): CRP is a marker of general inflammation, not specifically related to lipid peroxidation. It is synthesized by the liver in response to inflammatory cytokines and can be elevated in various conditions such as infections, autoimmune diseases, and cardiovascular conditions. While CRP reflects inflammation, it does not directly measure oxidative damage to lipids. B. hsCRP (high-sensitivity C-reactive protein): Like CRP, hsCRP is a more sensitive measure of inflammation, particularly in detecting low levels of systemic inflammation. It is often used to assess the risk of cardiovascular diseases. However, hsCRP is not a specific marker for lipid peroxidation or oxidative stress. C. Carboxymethyl lysine: Carboxymethyl lysine is a marker for advanced glycation end products (AGEs), which are formed when sugars bind to proteins, lipids, or nucleic acids. AGEs contribute to aging and the development of diabetic complications but are unrelated to lipid peroxidation.

questions.text: All are phospholipids except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ceramide. Ceramide is a type of sphingolipid, not a phospholipid. It is composed of a sphingosine backbone attached to a fatty acid, but it does not contain a phosphate group, which is the defining characteristic of phospholipids. Ceramides are important in the structure of cell membranes and are involved in signaling pathways related to cell growth, apoptosis, and stress responses. Since it lacks the phosphate group, ceramide is not classified as a phospholipid. Incorrect Options: B. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is a phospholipid found predominantly in the inner mitochondrial membrane. It contains two phosphatidic acid molecules linked by a glycerol backbone and plays an essential role in mitochondrial function and energy production. It is a phospholipid because it contains a phosphate group. C. Plasmalogen: Plasmalogen is a type of phospholipid that contains a vinyl ether linkage at the sn-1 position of the glycerol backbone, in addition to a phosphate group at the sn-3 position. Plasmalogens are found in high concentrations in the brain and heart and are important for cellular membrane function. D. Dipalmitoyl lecithin: Dipalmitoyl lecithin (also known as dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine) is a phospholipid, composed of a glycerol backbone, two fatty acids (palmitic acid), a phosphate group, and choline. It is a major component of pulmonary surfactant in the lungs, which reduces surface tension and prevents alveolar collapse.

questions.text: Hydrolysis of lecithin produces
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Choline. Lecithin is a type of phospholipid, specifically phosphatidylcholine, which is composed of a glycerol backbone, two fatty acids, a phosphate group, and choline. When lecithin undergoes hydrolysis (the breakdown by water), it produces glycerol, fatty acids, phosphate, and choline. Choline is an essential nutrient that is important for the synthesis of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter, and phosphatidylcholine, a major component of cell membranes. Therefore, hydrolysis of lecithin yields choline. Incorrect Options: A. Glycine: Glycine is an amino acid, not a product of lecithin hydrolysis. Lecithin does not contain glycine as part of its structure, so hydrolysis would not yield this compound. B. Pyruvate: Pyruvate is a key intermediate in cellular metabolism, particularly in glycolysis, but it is not produced during the hydrolysis of lecithin. Lecithin hydrolysis does not involve the breakdown of glucose or pyruvate. D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because, as explained, hydrolysis of lecithin indeed produces choline, which is listed as option C.

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipid does not contain glycerol
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sphingomyelin. Sphingomyelin is a phospholipid that does not contain glycerol as its backbone. Instead, it is composed of a sphingosine backbone, which is an amino alcohol. In sphingomyelin, the fatty acid is linked to the sphingosine backbone via an amide bond, and a phosphate group is attached to the sphingosine, which makes it a phospholipid. Sphingomyelin is commonly found in the cell membranes of nerve cells, particularly in the myelin sheath. Incorrect Options: A. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is a phospholipid that contains glycerol as its backbone. It consists of two phosphatidic acid molecules connected by a glycerol backbone and is primarily found in the inner mitochondrial membrane. B. Lecithin: Lecithin, also known as phosphatidylcholine, contains glycerol as its backbone. It is composed of glycerol, two fatty acids, a phosphate group, and choline. Lecithin is widely found in biological membranes and is a major component of lung surfactant. D. Ceramide: Ceramide is a sphingolipid, not a phospholipid, and it also does not contain glycerol. It is made up of a sphingosine backbone, a fatty acid, and is involved in cellular signaling and membrane structure. However, ceramide is not considered a phospholipid since it lacks a phosphate group.

questions.text: Cardiolipin is found in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Inner mitochondrial membrane. Cardiolipin is a unique phospholipid found primarily in the inner mitochondrial membrane. It consists of two phosphatidic acid molecules linked by a glycerol backbone, and it plays a crucial role in the function of mitochondria, particularly in maintaining the structure and stability of mitochondrial membrane proteins involved in oxidative phosphorylation. Cardiolipin is essential for the proper functioning of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complexes and ATP synthesis. Incorrect Options: A. Lysosomes: Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles responsible for breaking down waste materials and cellular debris. They contain phospholipids, but cardiolipin is not one of the major components of their membrane. The main lipid in lysosomal membranes is typically sphingolipids. B. Outer mitochondrial membrane: The outer mitochondrial membrane contains phospholipids like phosphatidylcholine and phosphatidylethanolamine, but cardiolipin is predominantly located in the inner mitochondrial membrane. The outer membrane is involved in the regulation of molecules entering and leaving the mitochondrion, not in energy production. D. Rough endoplasmic reticulum: The rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is involved in protein synthesis and modification. Its membrane contains phospholipids such as phosphatidylcholine, but cardiolipin is not a component of the ER membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the sphingomyelin
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Glycerol. Sphingomyelin is a sphingolipid and does not contain glycerol. Instead, it is composed of a sphingosine backbone, which is an amino alcohol, fatty acids, phosphoric acid (in the form of a phosphate group), and choline (which is attached to the phosphate group). Glycerol is found in phospholipids like lecithin and cardiolipin, but not in sphingomyelin. Incorrect Options: A. Sphingosine: Sphingosine is a key component of sphingomyelin. It forms the backbone of the molecule and is linked to a fatty acid via an amide bond. This makes it a fundamental structure in sphingolipids, including sphingomyelin. B. Choline: Choline is an essential component of sphingomyelin. It is attached to the phosphate group, making it a phospholipid. Choline plays a crucial role in cell membrane structure and function. D. Phosphoric acid: Phosphoric acid, in the form of a phosphate group, is an integral part of sphingomyelin. It is attached to the sphingosine backbone and links to choline, making sphingomyelin a phospholipid.

questions.text: Glycolipids are synthesized in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Endoplasmic reticulum. Glycolipids are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), specifically in the smooth ER. The process begins with the formation of ceramide (a type of sphingolipid) in the ER, and then the carbohydrate portion is added to form glycolipids. These glycolipids are crucial for the structure and function of cell membranes, particularly in the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane. The Golgi apparatus further modifies and sorts the glycolipids after their synthesis in the ER. Incorrect Options: A. Peroxisomes: Peroxisomes are involved in lipid metabolism, including the breakdown of fatty acids and the synthesis of plasmalogens. However, they are not involved in the synthesis of glycolipids. Their primary role is related to oxidative reactions and detoxification processes. B. Cytosol: The cytosol is the liquid component of the cytoplasm where many metabolic processes occur, but glycolipid synthesis does not take place directly in the cytosol. The cytosol may participate indirectly in metabolic pathways, but the actual synthesis of glycolipids occurs in the ER. D. Mitochondria: Mitochondria are responsible for energy production through oxidative phosphorylation and are involved in various metabolic processes like fatty acid oxidation. They do not play a direct role in the synthesis of glycolipids, which is carried out in the ER.

questions.text: Example of glycolipid is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cerebroside. Cerebrosides are a type of glycolipid, which are lipids containing a carbohydrate (usually a monosaccharide or oligosaccharide) attached to a ceramide (sphingosine backbone + fatty acid). Cerebrosides are important components of cell membranes, particularly in the brain and nervous tissue. They are involved in cellular recognition, signaling, and membrane stability. Incorrect Options: A. Plasmalogen: Plasmalogen is a type of phospholipid, not a glycolipid. It contains an ether bond at the sn-1 position of the glycerol backbone and is found in high concentrations in the heart and brain. Plasmalogens are involved in cellular protection and membrane fluidity but do not contain a carbohydrate group, which is a hallmark of glycolipids. B. Lecithin: Lecithin, also known as phosphatidylcholine, is a phospholipid, not a glycolipid. It contains choline, a phosphate group, and fatty acids attached to a glycerol backbone. Lecithin is abundant in cell membranes but does not have a carbohydrate group like glycolipids do. D. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is a sphingolipid, specifically a phospholipid that contains sphingosine as the backbone, with a phosphate group and choline attached. It does not contain a carbohydrate moiety, which is required for a lipid to be classified as a glycolipid.

questions.text: Simplest ganglioside is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) GM3 ganglioside. GM3 is the simplest ganglioside and consists of a ceramide backbone with a single sialic acid residue attached to a glycan chain. It is a monosialylated ganglioside, meaning it contains one sialic acid group. GM3 is involved in cell signaling and is found in various tissues, including the nervous system. It is the basic structure from which more complex gangliosides, such as GM1 and GM2, are derived. Incorrect Options: A. GM1 ganglioside: GM1 is a more complex ganglioside than GM3. It contains two sialic acid residues, one of which is linked to a galactose, making it a disialylated ganglioside. GM1 plays a crucial role in neuronal signaling and is involved in diseases like gangliosidosis. B. GM2 ganglioside: GM2 is an even more complex ganglioside than GM1. It contains three sialic acid residues and is involved in cell signaling and recognition processes. GM2 is associated with certain genetic disorders, such as Tay-Sachs disease. D. GM4 ganglioside: GM4 is a more complex ganglioside than GM3 and contains additional sugars in its structure. GM4 is involved in specific roles in the nervous system but is not the simplest ganglioside.

questions.text: Phospholipid with antigenic activity
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cardiolipin. Cardiolipin is a unique phospholipid that exhibits antigenic activity. It is found primarily in the inner mitochondrial membrane. Due to its distinctive structure, cardiolipin plays a role in immune responses and can trigger autoimmune reactions, especially in conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), where antibodies against cardiolipin can be present. This makes it antigenic, as it can provoke the production of specific antibodies in some autoimmune diseases. Incorrect Options: B. Plasmalogen: Plasmalogens are a type of phospholipid that are found in cell membranes, particularly in the brain and heart. While plasmalogens have important roles in cellular protection and membrane fluidity, they do not have significant antigenic activity. They are not known to trigger immune responses in the same way as cardiolipin. C. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is a type of sphingolipid and is an important component of the cell membrane, particularly in the myelin sheath of nerve cells. It does not have antigenic properties and does not typically trigger immune responses. Sphingomyelin is crucial for maintaining membrane structure and function. D. Phosphatidylcholine: Phosphatidylcholine, also known as lecithin, is a major component of biological membranes and is involved in lipid bilayer formation. While it is important for cell membrane structure and function, it does not have antigenic activity and is not known to provoke immune responses like cardiolipin.

questions.text: Barth syndrome is due to defect in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cardiolipin. Barth syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by defects in the gene responsible for the synthesis of cardiolipin, a phospholipid primarily found in the inner mitochondrial membrane. Cardiolipin is crucial for maintaining mitochondrial function, including the stability and activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain. A defect in cardiolipin results in impaired mitochondrial function, leading to symptoms like cardiomyopathy, muscle weakness, and neutropenia, which are characteristic of Barth syndrome. Incorrect Options: A. Cytochrome: Cytochromes are heme-containing proteins involved in electron transport within mitochondria. While cytochromes are crucial for mitochondrial energy production, they are not directly linked to Barth syndrome. The disorder is caused by a defect in cardiolipin, not cytochromes. C. Ubiquinone: Ubiquinone (also known as coenzyme Q10) is involved in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, transferring electrons between cytochromes. Although it plays a role in mitochondrial energy production, it is not the cause of Barth syndrome. Barth syndrome is linked to defective cardiolipin synthesis, not a defect in ubiquinone. D. Thermogenin: Thermogenin, also known as uncoupling protein 1 (UCP1), is involved in thermogenesis in brown adipose tissue. It helps dissipate energy as heat rather than storing it as ATP. Thermogenin is not implicated in Barth syndrome, which is specifically caused by a defect in cardiolipin.

questions.text: Sphingolipids are mainly accumulate in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CNS. Sphingolipids are primarily found in the central nervous system (CNS), especially in the brain and spinal cord. These lipids play a crucial role in the formation of myelin sheaths, which insulate nerve fibers and facilitate the efficient transmission of electrical signals. Sphingolipids, such as sphingomyelin and cerebrosides, are abundant in neuronal membranes and are critical for the structural integrity and function of the CNS. Incorrect Options: A. Skeletal muscle: While sphingolipids are present in skeletal muscle, their concentration is not as high as in the CNS. In muscle tissue, sphingolipids contribute to cell membrane structure and function but are not the predominant lipid type. B. Adipose tissue: Adipose tissue primarily stores triglycerides, which are composed of glycerol and fatty acids. Sphingolipids are not the main lipid component in adipose tissue; they are more prevalent in nervous tissue. D. Cardiac muscle: Sphingolipids are also present in cardiac muscle, where they contribute to membrane structure and signaling. However, like skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle does not accumulate sphingolipids to the extent seen in the CNS.

questions.text: Eicosanoids are derived from which fatty acid
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Arachidonic acid. Eicosanoids, which include prostaglandins, leukotrienes, thromboxanes, and prostacyclins, are bioactive lipid mediators derived from arachidonic acid, a polyunsaturated fatty acid. Arachidonic acid is released from membrane phospholipids by the enzyme phospholipase A2 and then metabolized by cyclooxygenase (COX), lipoxygenase (LOX), or cytochrome P450 enzymes into various eicosanoids. These molecules play important roles in inflammation, immunity, blood clotting, and other physiological processes. Incorrect Options: A. Linolenic acid: Linolenic acid is an essential omega-3 fatty acid that is important for health, but it is not the direct precursor of eicosanoids. While it can be converted into eicosanoids, the primary eicosanoid-producing fatty acid is arachidonic acid. B. Linoleic acid: Linoleic acid is an essential omega-6 fatty acid, and although it can be converted into arachidonic acid (the precursor to eicosanoids), linoleic acid itself is not directly converted into eicosanoids. It is the precursor to arachidonic acid, which is then metabolized to form eicosanoids. C. Oleic acid: Oleic acid is a monounsaturated fatty acid and does not serve as a precursor for eicosanoids. While oleic acid has several health benefits, it is not involved in the production of eicosanoids, which require polyunsaturated fatty acids like arachidonic acid.

choices.text: Chain elongation and one desaturation of linoleic acid
Chain elongation and two desaturation of linoleic acid
Chain elongation and one desaturation of linolenic acid

questions.text: Arachidonic acid is produced in mammals by which process
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Chain elongation and two desaturation of linoleic acid. In mammals, arachidonic acid is synthesized from linoleic acid, an essential omega-6 fatty acid. The process involves two main steps: first, chain elongation of linoleic acid to form a longer fatty acid, and then two desaturation steps to introduce double bonds into the elongated fatty acid chain. This process ultimately converts linoleic acid into arachidonic acid, which is crucial for the synthesis of eicosanoids, such as prostaglandins, thromboxanes, and leukotrienes. Incorrect Options: A. Chain elongation and one desaturation of linoleic acid: While chain elongation and desaturation are involved in the synthesis of arachidonic acid, the process requires two desaturation steps, not just one. One desaturation step would not lead to the formation of arachidonic acid from linoleic acid. C. Chain elongation and one desaturation of linolenic acid: Linolenic acid is an omega-3 fatty acid and is involved in the synthesis of eicosanoids, but it is not the direct precursor of arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid is derived from linoleic acid, not linolenic acid. D. Elongation of stearic acid: Stearic acid is a saturated fatty acid, and its elongation does not lead to the formation of arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid is derived from polyunsaturated fatty acids like linoleic acid, not from saturated fatty acids like stearic acid.

questions.text: Mixture of lipid is separated by which method
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Chromatography. Chromatography is a powerful technique used to separate mixtures of lipids (or other compounds) based on their chemical properties such as polarity, size, or charge. Various types of chromatography, such as thin-layer chromatography (TLC) or gas chromatography (GC), are commonly employed for lipid separation. This technique works by passing the lipid mixture through a stationary phase (e.g., a column or a plate) with a mobile phase (e.g., a solvent), which causes different lipids to move at different rates, leading to their separation. Incorrect Options: A. PAGE (Polyacrylamide Gel Electrophoresis): PAGE is a method used to separate proteins, not lipids. It uses an electric field to separate molecules based on their size and charge. While PAGE can be used for the separation of protein-lipid complexes or lipoproteins, it is not typically used for separating pure lipid mixtures. C. Isoelectric focusing: Isoelectric focusing is a technique primarily used to separate proteins based on their isoelectric point (pH at which a protein has no net charge). It is not used for separating lipids, as lipids do not have a defined isoelectric point. D. Electrophoresis: Electrophoresis is a method used for the separation of charged particles (like proteins or nucleic acids) in an electric field. While lipids are not inherently charged, electrophoresis can be adapted to separate lipids if they are first chemically modified to carry charge. However, chromatography is the preferred method for lipid separation.
